Expectation1: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation1: Before starting structural work, the carpenter needs to inspect and maintain tools and equipment to ensure safety and efficiency
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: I glanced at my watch, heart pounding. The sun was barely up, but already a line of people waited outside the community center, shuffling their feet in the morning chill. As the only volunteer scheduled to open up, I knew they were counting on me to be on time. But at the same moment, I stood in the workshop, surrounded by saws and drills that needed a thorough inspection before I could start the day’s carpentry work. My boss had drilled it into me: safety first, always. If I skipped checking the tools, I risked an accident—maybe not today, but someday. Yet, if I stayed, the people outside would keep waiting, some of them elderly, some with kids, all depending on the center’s warmth and services. My hands hovered over the toolbox, torn between the responsibility to my trade and the promise I’d made as a volunteer. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding my presence, each unwilling to wait.
